    Lizzie King

    Assistant Professor

    • Athens, Georgia
    • Website

    Lizzie is now an assistant professor at the Odum School of Ecology and at the Warnell School of Forestry & Natural Resources at the University of Georgia, studying sustainability in African dryland social-ecological systems, and more recently, restoration in tidal marshes on the Georgia coast.

    Lizzie King's Recent News

    Two articles recently accepted in Hydrology and Earth System Sciences

    Article accepted in Water Resources Research

    Article to be published in Ecohydrology

    Lizzie King accepts a faculty position at the University of Georgia

    Commentary to be published in Ecohydrology

    Article accepted in Water Resources Research

    WAVES Lab Publications by Lizzie King

    δ2H isotopic flux partitioning of evapotranspiration over a grass field following a water pulse and subsequent dry down

    Good, S. P., K. Soderberg, K. Guan, E. G. King, T. M. Scanlon, and K. K. Caylor (2014), δ2H isotopic flux partitioning of evapotranspiration over a grass field following a water pulse and subsequent dry down, Water Resour. Res., 50, 1410–1432, doi:10.1002/ 2013WR014333.

    An ecohydrological approach to predicting hillslope-scale vegetation patterns in dryland ecosystems

    *Franz, T.E., Caylor, K.K., *King, E.G., Nordbotten, J., Celia, M.A., Rodriguez-Iturbe, I, (2012) “An ecohydrological approach to predicting hillslope-scale vegetation patterns in dryland ecosystems”, Water Resources Research, doi:10.1029/ 2011WR010524.

    Reframing hydrology education to solve coupled human and environmental problems

    ∗King, E.G., ∗O’Donnell, F.C., Caylor, K.K. (2012) “Reframing hydrology education to solve coupled human and environmental problems”, Hydrology and Earth System Science, doi:10.5194/hess-16-4023-2012.

    Ecohydrology in practice: Strengths, conveniences, and opportunities

    *King, E.G., Caylor, K.K. (2011) “Ecohydrology in practice: Strengths, conveniences, and opportunities”, Ecohydrology,4(4), 608-612, doi: 10.1002/ eco.248.

    Herbivores and mutualistic ants interact to modify tree photosynthesis

    *King, E.G., Caylor, K.K. (2010) “Herbivores and mutualistic ants interact to modify tree photosynthesis,” New Phytologist, 187, p17-21, doi: 10.1111/ j.1469-8137.2010.03286.x.
